perturbation.original_text:
The invoices will be issued by EIT at the start of each term. Such invoice must be paid by the customer within 45 days of the date on which the
invoice is issued.
perturbation.changed_text: The invoices will be issued by EIT at the start of each term. Such invoice must be paid by the customer within 30 days of the date on which the invoice is issued, unless otherwise agreed in writing by both parties. However, for the first invoice, the customer has 60 days to make the payment.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces an in-text contradiction by stipulating a standard payment term of 30 days while simultaneously providing a special payment window of 60 days specifically for the initial invoice. This conflicts with the general payment terms and creates uncertainty regarding the applicable payment deadline.

perturbation.original_text:
The present Agreement is effective as from 1 January 2009. It is established by calendar year and renewed tacitly every year.
 
 
The Agreement rests, for all that, cancellable at any time by any of the parties before the expiry date of the Agreement or any of its
renewals, upon three months prior written notice.
perturbation.changed_text:
The present Agreement is effective as from 1 January 2009. It is established by calendar year and renewed tacitly every year.

The Agreement rests, for all that, cancellable only after the initial term of one year by any of the parties before the expiry date of the Agreement or any of its renewals, upon three months prior written notice. However, EIT can cancel the present agreement at any time, providing a one-month prior written notice.
perturbation.explanation: This change creates an in-text contradiction concerning the conditions under which the contract can be cancelled. Initially, either party can cancel at any time with three months' notice. The modified clause restricts the customer to cancelling only after the initial one-year term, while simultaneously allowing EIT to cancel at any time with just one month's notice. This is contradictory and creates ambiguity and unfair imbalance in cancellation rights.

perturbation.original_text: The liability of EIT will be limited to a value equal to contractual value as per clause 7.1 and will not exceed this value.
perturbation.changed_text: The liability of EIT will be limited to a value equal to 50% of the annual contractual value as per clause 7.1 and will not exceed this value, unless the damages are a result of gross negligence or willful misconduct by EIT, in which case the liability is unlimited.
perturbation.explanation: This amendment creates an in-text contradiction by initially limiting EIT's liability to 50% of the annual contract value. However, it simultaneously introduces an exception stating that if the damages result from EIT's gross negligence or willful misconduct, the liability becomes unlimited. This creates ambiguity and undermines the initial liability limitation, making it unclear what the actual liability cap is.
